HONOR SYSTEM RULES
_0_
Undergraduate Committee Appointed—New Rules Presented.
Each of the undergraduate classes
having expressed itself as in favor of
the adoption of the Honor System,
the task of drafting a set of rules
to govern the practical working of
the system is now being taken up. A
Committee consisting of two representatives from each class is now at
work on these rules, and the result
of their efforts will be presented to
the different classes and the faculty
for adoption. The members of this
Committee are, Theodore S. Will
and Ross Veazey for the seniors:
Richard S. McCabe and Edmund S.
Clary for the juniors; Williams
Haynes and T. Brooke Price for the
sophomores, and E. J. Pieper and
George Gillet for the freshmen.
Beside the rules proposed by the
Juniors a set have come to the Committee with the endorsement of the
sophomore class. In order that the
undergraduate body at large may
have an opportunity of comparing
these two plans for the practical
Working of the Honor System we
Print the rules as formulated by the
Sophomore Committee.
To the Honor System Committee:
The class of 1912 have voted favorably on the following prepared
rules, which we submit for your consideration:
First. Each student by his entrance into the University accepts
the Honor System, which shall govern all final, entrance, condition, term,
and special examinations, and all
Written quizes, but shall not govern
regular examinations for admission.
ach student upon entering the University, when he first goes to his
adviser, who shall witness the same,
Shall sign the following pledge.
"I hereby pledge my word of
honor to neither directly or indirect1Y give or receive any help whatsoever during any written examination or quiz while an undergraduate
student at Johns Hopkins University
.and I further pledge my word of
honor to report anyone whosoever I
Shall know to have broken the first
clause of this pledge."
Moreover, each student shall make
the following declaration at the end
Of each
written examination or
quiz paper:
"I give my word of honor that I
have neither given nor received aid

during this examination (quiz)."

in the U. S., at that time, met Mr.
D. L. Moody, the evangelist, on a
train. He asked Mr. Moody if he
could not bring ten or fifteen students to Northfield in the summer for
Mr. Moody to give them a course of
Bible study. Mr. Moody told him to
bring fifty, as he could teach fifty

Class 1899—The new pathological
Massachusetts

charge of Dr. Frederick H. Verhoeff
patholOgist to the hospital.

Lacrosse practice has been taken

and barring the goal keeper, a position that is giving the coaches a good
deal of trouble, they have a plentiful
supply of material. They have six
of last year's team back, and a goodly number of last season's "scrubs."
Their home games include the Carlisle Indians, Harvard, Cornell, the
New York Lacrosse Club and Hopkins.

ALUMNI NOTES
L. Allen Dill, '05, a former lacrosse star, has announced his engagement to Miss Margaret Chambers of this city.

Mr. Wishard invited the college
students to attend and 250 instead of
50 responded to the call. This was
the first student summer Conference
at Northfield. At this Conference,
the Student Volunteer Movement was
organized and ioo of the students
offered themselves as ready for service on the foreign field.
From this time forth the Conference grew in numbers and influence.
At length the colleges in other sections of the country felt the need of
such a conference in their sections,
and now there are seven such conferences held every year in different
parts of the country attended by hundreds of college men.
The main portion of the Johns
Hopkins delegation has always attended Northfield, although representatives have been present at the
Lake Geneva and Asheville Conferences.
For several years, there has been
a demand form the colleges of New
Jersey, Pennsylvania, and Maryland
for an earlier conference than Northfield and one which would be held
further South.
The Northfield Conference has
grown to such large proportions that
it was deemed advisable last year to
separate the. conference and hold
another in the Mountains of Pennsylvania for the colleges in the Middle Atlantic States.
This year Johns Hopkins will go
to this Conference and a much largThe
er delegation should be sent.

that a man can be back the first of
July in time for a summer job. The

"England and theFrenchRevolution
1789-1797;" by William Thomas Laprade. Dissertation.
The latest publication of the Johns
Hopkins Press is a substantial, and
yet interesting contribution to the
knowledge of the French Revolution
and its effect on English public opinion.
Dr. Laprade undertook his
study with the purpose of showing
to what extent the English social and
political life of the period contemporaneous with the French Revolution was influenced by that event, or,
in other words, whether the popular
agitations in England, which attracted the attention of the English government at this time owed their origin to the revolution taking place in
France. Some of these conditions in
England were, the author says due
to inside influences, but nevertheless the effect which the French
Revolution had upon the political
tho' ght of the great English leaders
such as Pitt, Burke and other cabinet officials is noticeable.
The author, after what must have
been a vast amount of work in the
libraries of Baltimore, Washington,
and London, has analyzed very carefully and critically the influence
which worked upon the political literature of the day and the corresinnding reaction upon the policies of
the goN ernr lent.
Dr. Laprade presents the following conclusions: "In its early stages
the French Revolution was regarded favorably by the majority of Engw%s corr;dered a subject rather for speculation than as
vital to the interests of England.
Gradually the favorable view of the
revolution gave way to one that was
distinctly hostile, due as it is commonly supposed to the writings of
Edmund Burke. We believe, however, that this change of opinion may
be attributed in a slight measure, if
at all, to the advocacy of the great
orator, but unexpected by the deliberate efforts of the adherents of William Pitt in order to secure his political advantage. .
..
"It is therefore, reasonable to conclude that the uprising in France playedbut a minor role in the dramatic history of England in the years from
1789 to 1797, except as far as it was
used by Pitt and his colleagues for
their own political purposes as a future and for reviving the old time
struggle with France for supremacy
in the commercial and the colonial
world."
Dr. Laprade's conclusion seems to
indicate that the research which he
has done was useless, except so far
as it affected Pitt and his associates.
A better title for the work, it seems
to us, would have been English Public Opinion and the French Revolution, with incidental allusions to Pitt
and his followers in so far as their
opinions were part of the political
thought of the time. Then the volume would have made a capital coin-

21,

1910.

panion work to"Contemporary American Opinions of the French Revolution," by C. D. Hazen, published as
an extra volume to the "Studies."
Now, after being told in the preface
that the work is to treat the effect
upon "the English Social Organization as a Whole," and learning that
the real effect is upon Pitt, the scope
of the study seems to have been
greatly narrowed and the vast amount
of literature which explored seems to
have no bearing upon the conclusion.
In other words, there was no reference upon England as a whole; therefore the title is misleading. The influence upon Pitt forms only a small
part of the work and so the rest is
useless. The better method, as we
have said, would have been to treat
the political thought as a whole,
and make conclusions with regard
to it.
INTERCOLLEGIATE ITEMS
Congratulations to Columbia for
having a president who came out openly in favor of academic credit being given to managers of athletic
teams, musical and dramatic clubs,
and editors of college publications.
Purdue has refused to grant the
athletic insignia to its football team
this season on the ground that it was
not up to the usual standard. It does
not seem as if they were adopting
the surest course to raise that same
standard.
Pennsylvania won the prize at
the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition
for the best educational exhibit.

SUGGESTION FOR NEW
SONG
To the Editor of The News-Letter.
Dear Sir:
Tread with much interest the letter published several weeks ago in
your paper which claimed that the
Hopkins has no real college song.
I think, as an editorial in your paper suggested, that a great many
songs should be written, and then the
best one should be selected. I hope
you will excuse my asking you to
use your valuable space to print the
following, on the ground that it was
the best songs has been selected, any
written to start the ball rolling. After
of the musicians at the Hopkins, I
feel sure, could write some appropriate tune for it.
Reader.
Rally, rally round the flag, boys,
Forget every care we knew,
For today is the day we sing, boys,
In praise of the black and blue.
For the days of "lab" and days of
tests,
Then far in the past will be,
And, 0. then we'll know that friendship true,
Was the truth that made us free.
Rally, rally round the flag, boys,
For we are loyal sons and true,
And we'll ne'er forget the victories
Won 'neath the black and the blue.
Rally, rally round the flag, boys,
For few the years that yet remain
To sing the praise of the days we
spent
And to raise the final strain.

NATURALISTS' CLUE
The Naturalists' Field Club listened to a very instructive lecture on
pearls last Thursday week. It was
delivered by Mr. C. W. Wilson,
a graduate student in Biology, who
has been doing work in this field for
the government for some time past.
He explained in interesting detail
how the different forms of pearls
are made by the fresh water mussels:
the "blisters" caused by injury to the
shell; the "baroques" resulting from
some foreign substance getting in
the shell; and the really perfect
pearl coming from wounds caused by
parasitic worms. He also pointed
.out how important an industry is
growing up in pearls and told of the
igovernment's efforts to foster it by
establishing mussel breeding stations
in the Middle West.

Professor Laird of Pennsylvania,
says, "German Universities stand
for scholarship; English Universities for culture; American Universities for service." Wish the Professor had been a little more definite:
We have so many kinds of service
these days all the way from Public
Service Commissions down to the
Wide-a-wake Clean Towel Service.

Undergraduate Committee Appointed—New Rules Presented.
Each of the undergraduate classes
having expressed itself as in favor of
the adoption of the Honor System,
the task of drafting a set of rules
to govern the practical working of
the system is now being taken up. A
Committee consisting of two representatives from each class is now at
work on these rules, and the result
of their efforts will be presented to
the different classes and the faculty
for adoption. The members of this
Committee are, Theodore S. Will
and Ross Veazey for the seniors:
Richard S. McCabe and Edmund S.
Clary for the juniors; Williams
Haynes and T. Brooke Price for the
sophomores, and E. J. Pieper and
George Gillet for the freshmen.
Beside the rules proposed by the
Juniors a set have come to the Committee with the endorsement of the
sophomore class. In order that the
undergraduate body at large may
have an opportunity of comparing
these two plans for the practical
Working of the Honor System we
Print the rules as formulated by the
Sophomore Committee.

"England and theFrenchRevolution
1789-1797;" by William Thomas Laprade. Dissertation.
The latest publication of the Johns
Hopkins Press is a substantial, and
yet interesting contribution to the
knowledge of the French Revolution
and its effect on English public opinion.
Dr. Laprade undertook his
study with the purpose of showing
to what extent the English social and
political life of the period contemporaneous with the French Revolution was influenced by that event, or,
in other words, whether the popular
agitations in England, which attracted the attention of the English government at this time owed their origin to the revolution taking place in
France. Some of these conditions in
England were, the author says due
to inside influences, but nevertheless the effect which the French
Revolution had upon the political
tho' ght of the great English leaders
such as Pitt, Burke and other cabinet officials is noticeable.
The author, after what must have
been a vast amount of work in the
libraries of Baltimore, Washington,
and London, has analyzed very carefully and critically the influence
which worked upon the political literature of the day and the corresinnding reaction upon the policies of
the goN ernr lent.
Dr. Laprade presents the following conclusions: "In its early stages
the French Revolution was regarded favorably by the majority of Engw%s corr;dered a subject rather for speculation than as
vital to the interests of England.
Gradually the favorable view of the
revolution gave way to one that was
distinctly hostile, due as it is commonly supposed to the writings of
Edmund Burke. We believe, however, that this change of opinion may
be attributed in a slight measure, if
at all, to the advocacy of the great
orator, but unexpected by the deliberate efforts of the adherents of William Pitt in order to secure his political advantage. .
..
"It is therefore, reasonable to conclude that the uprising in France playedbut a minor role in the dramatic history of England in the years from
1789 to 1797, except as far as it was
used by Pitt and his colleagues for
their own political purposes as a future and for reviving the old time
struggle with France for supremacy
in the commercial and the colonial
world."
Dr. Laprade's conclusion seems to
indicate that the research which he
has done was useless, except so far
as it affected Pitt and his associates.
A better title for the work, it seems
to us, would have been English Public Opinion and the French Revolution, with incidental allusions to Pitt
and his followers in so far as their
opinions were part of the political
thought of the time. Then the volume would have made a capital coin-

21,

1910.

panion work to"Contemporary American Opinions of the French Revolution," by C. D. Hazen, published as
an extra volume to the "Studies."
Now, after being told in the preface
that the work is to treat the effect
upon "the English Social Organization as a Whole," and learning that
the real effect is upon Pitt, the scope
of the study seems to have been
greatly narrowed and the vast amount
of literature which explored seems to
have no bearing upon the conclusion.
In other words, there was no reference upon England as a whole; therefore the title is misleading. The influence upon Pitt forms only a small
part of the work and so the rest is
useless. The better method, as we
have said, would have been to treat
the political thought as a whole,
and make conclusions with regard
to it.
INTERCOLLEGIATE ITEMS
Congratulations to Columbia for
having a president who came out openly in favor of academic credit being given to managers of athletic

and editors of college publications.
Purdue has refused to grant the
athletic insignia to its football team
this season on the ground that it was
not up to the usual standard. It does
not seem as if they were adopting
the surest course to raise that same
standard.
Pennsylvania won the prize at
the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition
for the best educational exhibit.

SUGGESTION FOR NEW
SONG
To the Editor of The News-Letter.
Dear Sir:
Tread with much interest the letter published several weeks ago in
your paper which claimed that the
Hopkins has no real college song.
I think, as an editorial in your paper suggested, that a great many
songs should be written, and then the
best one should be selected. I hope
you will excuse my asking you to
use your valuable space to print the
following, on the ground that it was
the best songs has been selected, any
written to start the ball rolling. After
of the musicians at the Hopkins, I
feel sure, could write some appropriate tune for it.
Reader.
Rally, rally round the flag, boys,
Forget every care we knew,
For today is the day we sing, boys,
In praise of the black and blue.
For the days of "lab" and days of
tests,
Then far in the past will be,
And, 0. then we'll know that friendship true,
Was the truth that made us free.
Rally, rally round the flag, boys,
For we are loyal sons and true,
And we'll ne'er forget the victories
Won 'neath the black and the blue.
Rally, rally round the flag, boys,
For few the years that yet remain
To sing the praise of the days we
spent
And to raise the final strain.

NATURALISTS' CLUE
The Naturalists' Field Club listened to a very instructive lecture on
pearls last Thursday week. It was
delivered by Mr. C. W. Wilson,
a graduate student in Biology, who
has been doing work in this field for
the government for some time past.
He explained in interesting detail
how the different forms of pearls
are made by the fresh water mussels:
the "blisters" caused by injury to the
shell; the "baroques" resulting from
some foreign substance getting in
the shell; and the really perfect
pearl coming from wounds caused by
parasitic worms. He also pointed
.out how important an industry is
growing up in pearls and told of the
igovernment's efforts to foster it by
establishing mussel breeding stations
in the Middle West.

Professor Laird of Pennsylvania,
says, "German Universities stand
for scholarship; English Universities for culture; American Universities for service." Wish the Professor had been a little more definite:
We have so many kinds of service
these days all the way from Public
Service Commissions down to the
Wide-a-wake Clean Towel Service.

with suspicion upon their scholars
and their teachings. We sniff at
their courses for waiters, for blacksmiths, for trained nurses. We laugh
at their social functions, at which
magnificent collations are always

thank the Lord that we are not as
they. And yet there is at least one
lesson that Hopkins might learn
from these wild and wooly institutions. At one of the State Universities—and it is these State affairs
that are farthest from the Pale—a
new stand was needed on the athletic
